Screen.title: TopScreen
Screen.Label: ---------- Mouse Button 1 click on field to change ----------

Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
psninv - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Screen.title: psninv Process
Screen.Label: PreStack Non-Linear Inversion products (PSNINV)
General Parameters
OPT_INPUT=
OPT_OUTPUT=
NUMTR_IN=
NUMTR_OUT=
ANG_REF=
Noise Parameters
Hyperbolic Win Parameters
Flags for Time-Lapse
MEDIAN=
T0_MIN=
FLAG_AVO=
T0_MAX=
FLAG_REGU=
FLAG_NOISE=
Iteration Parameters
MAX_ITER=
IPM_ITER=
CG_ITER=
Bounds on Intercept & Gradient Parameters
INTERCEPT_BOUND=
GRADIENT_BOUND=
Specify the Path for the Velocity file and the name
OPT_AVE=
LEN_SMOOTH=
OPT_SR=
Specify the starting and output wavelet parameters
TIM_FIRST=
LEN_OP=

Help.Tip: Input CMPs in angle or offset or intercept-gradient pairs.
Help.Text:
psninv - OPT_INPUT
Input CMPs in angle or offset or intercept-gradient pairs.
 
 Default = OFFSET
 Allowed = OFFSET    (Input consists of ordinary CMP gathers in offset.)
 
 If OPT_INPUT = OFFSET, header word 6 must contain offset.

Help.Tip: Type of AVA gradient related output product.
Help.Text:
psninv - OPT_OUTPUT
Type of AVA gradient related output product.
 
 Default = A_B_SRC
 Allowed = A_B_SRC  (Intercept, Gradient and Source.)
 Allowed = DA_DB_SRC (Perturbed Intercept, Perturbed Gradient and Source.)
 Allowed = S_REFL   (Estimated S-wave reflectivity at normal incidence + Src.)
 Allowed = P_REFL   (Modeled P-wave reflectivity at angle ANG_REF. + Source)
 Allowed = VS_VP    (Estimated VS/VP ratio + Source.)
 Allowed = AB_PROD  (Product of Intercept times Gradient + Source.)
 Allowed = MODEL    (Predicted data + a,b,source trace.)
 Allowed = RESID    (Observed(input) data - Predicted Data + a,b,source trace.)
 
 
 OPT_OUTPUT = A_B_SRC produces a 3-trace output gather from each input gather.
 
 OPT_OUTPUT = DA_DB_SRC produces a 3-trace output gather from input gather.
 
 OPT_OUTPUT = P_REFL, S_REFL, VS_VP or AB_PROD produces a two output trace
 from each input gather.
 
 OPT_OUTPUT = MODEL or RESID produces output gathers of the same size as the
 input gathers plus three more traces for a, b, and source.

Help.Tip: Value of NUMTR global upon input, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
psninv - NUMTR_IN
Value of NUMTR global upon input, shown for reference.
 
 psninv requires gathered input. NUMTR for your input traces must be at
 least 2 for all options, and must be exactly 2 when OPT_INPUT = A_B_SRC
 or DA_DB_SRC.

Help.Tip: Value of NUMTR global upon output, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
psninv - NUMTR_OUT
Value of NUMTR global upon output, shown for reference.
 
 The value of NUMTR for your output traces depends on OPT_OUTPUT.
 NUMTR_OUT will be 3 when OPT_OUTPUT = A_B_SRC, DA_DB_SRC.
 NUMTR_OUT will be 2 when OPT_OUTPUT = P_REFL, S_REFL, VS_VP or AB_PROD.
 NUMTR_OUT will be the same as NUMTR_IN + 3 when OPT_OUTPUT = MODEL or RESID.

Help.Tip: Reference angle to use, in degrees, when OPT_OUTPUT = P_REFL.
Help.Text:
psninv - ANG_REF
Reference angle to use, in degrees, when OPT_OUTPUT = P_REFL.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = 90.0 >= real >= 0.0
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT = P_REFL.

Help.Tip: Standard Deviation for Median Noise estimate in Percentage
Help.Text:
psninv - MEDIAN
Standard Deviation for Median Noise estimate in Percentage
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = (0,1)
 
 MEDIAN provides the noise estimate in the data. Typically this is
 expressed in percentage. Thus MEDIAN=1.0 means that the standard
 deviation of the data is 100% of the median value in the specified
 window. The window is defined by T0_MIN and T0_MAX

Help.Tip: Minimum zero-offset time for the hyperbolic window
Help.Text:
psninv - T0_MIN
Minimum zero-offset time for the hyperbolic window
 
 Default = begining of the trace. But this will make the code
           code run slower since it will invert all of the data.
           Also the AVO model will try to fit zeros if no signal is
           available.
 Allowed = specify the starting time for the window in seconds

Help.Tip: Flag for including the base AVO model in the time lapse inversion
Help.Text:
psninv - FLAG_AVO
Flag for including the base AVO model in the time lapse inversion
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = integer 0,1
 If FLAG_AVO = 1, then the reference or base model for AVO will be read from
 data file. Note that first two traces of each gather will be the intercept
 and gradient trace obtained from previous inversion.

Help.Tip: Maximum zero-offset time for the hyperbolic window
Help.Text:
psninv - T0_MAX
Maximum zero-offset time for the hyperbolic window
 
 Default = end of the trace. This will make the code run slower
           since it will invert all of the data till end of trace
 Allowed = end the starting time for the window in seconds

Help.Tip: Flag for including the previous regularization in time lapse inversion
Help.Text:
psninv - FLAG_REGU
Flag for including the previous regularization in time lapse inversion
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = integer 0,1
 If FLAG_REGU = 1, then the previous regularization will be read from the
 data file. Note that the regularization parameter from previous inversion
 is extracted from the header word of the first trace i.e. intercept trace.

Help.Tip: Flag to include the previous noise estimate in the time lapse inversion
Help.Text:
psninv - FLAG_NOISE
Flag to include the previous noise estimate in the time lapse inversion
 
 Default = 0
 Allowed = integer 0,1
 If FLAG_NOISE = 1, then the previous noise estimate will be read from the
 data file. Note that the noise parameter from previous inversion
 is extracted from the header word of the first trace i.e. intercept trace.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of iterations in the inversion
Help.Text:
psninv - MAX_ITER
Maximum number of iterations in the inversion
 
 Default = 5.0
 Allowed = > 1
 
 MAX_ITER is the maximum number of iterations allowed in the
 inversion. Typically the inversion will run upto MAX_ITER if
 it doesnot converge with the specifed noise level.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of interior point iterations
Help.Text:
psninv - IPM_ITER
Maximum number of interior point iterations
 
 Default = 6.0
 Allowed = > 1
 
 IPM_ITER is the maximum number of iterations allowed in the
 interior point optimization procedure. The default is 6
 and can be increased if the barrier parameter do not
 decrease sufficiently. In most cases 6-8 iterations is
 enough at each regularization step.

Help.Tip: Maximum number of CG Iteration for solving system of equation
Help.Text:
psninv - CG_ITER
Maximum number of CG Iteration for solving system of equation
 
 Default = 20
 Allowed = > 20
 
 CG_ITER is the maximum number of conjugate gradient iterations allowed in the
 solving the system. This number depends on the size of the system. However
 allowing number of iterations equal to size will be very expensive. Thus few
 iterations (> 20) is sufficient to give an approximate solution to the linear
 system. Note that an approximate solution for system of eq. is all we need to
 solve the nonlinear inverse problem.

Help.Tip: Bound for the intercept parameter (a)
Help.Text:
psninv - INTERCEPT_BOUND
Bound for the intercept parameter (a)
 
 Default = 0.2
 Allowed = (0,1)
 
 INTERCEPT_BOUND provides the bound for the intercept parameter. For example
 if the specified bound is 0.2 then -0.2 <= a <= 0.2 is imposed in inversion.
 Note that |a  + bsin(theta)^2| <= 1. The program will change the bnd if user
 specifies bound that are greater than unity (>1). The change is proportinal
 for the intercept and gradient, such that total refelctivity < 1.

Help.Tip: Bound for the gradient parameter (b)
Help.Text:
psninv - GRADIENT_BOUND
Bound for the gradient parameter (b)
 
 Default = 0.2
 Allowed = (0,1)
 
 GRADIENT_BOUND provides the bound for the gradient parameter. For example
 if the specified bound is 0.2 then -0.2 <= b <= 0.2 is imposed in inversion.
 Note that |a  + bsin(theta)^2| <= 1. The program will change the bnd if user
 specifies bound that are greater than unity (>1). The change is proportinal
 for the intercept and gradient, such that total refelctivity < unity.

Help.Tip: Choose PATH_VEL using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
psninv - SELECT_PATH_VEL
Choose PATH_VEL using a file selection dialog box.
 
 Active only when OPT_INPUT = OFFSET.

Help.Tip: Pathname for a stacking or interval velocity file.
Help.Text:
psninv - PATH_VEL
Pathname for a stacking or interval velocity file.
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 A velocity file is needed to carryout the forward modeling that
 applies the moveout on the data. Note that Stacking velocity
 (NMO) is used in the forward modeling. However if interval velocity
 file is provided, the code computes the NMO velocity using
 interval to NMO velocity relation.
 
 Active only when OPT_INPUT = OFFSET.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_VEL.
Help.Text:
psninv - PATH_VEL_INFO
Status of PATH_VEL.

Help.Tip: Whether to average all velocity functions in the file into one.
Help.Text:
psninv - OPT_AVE
Whether to average all velocity functions in the file into one.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 Whether to average all velocity functions in the file to a single velocity
 function.
 
 As in process AVAST, the intent of OPT_AVE = NO is to be able to accommodate
 a SLOWLY varying water depth. It is up to you to put in functions which have
 a smooth lateral variation. It is NOT recommended that the option be used
 with raw stacking velocites.

Help.Tip: Length of running average smoothing for interval velocities.
Help.Text:
psninv - LEN_SMOOTH
Length of running average smoothing for interval velocities.
 
 Default = 0.2
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 Length, in seconds, of running average smoothing for interval velocity
 functions.  If LEN_SMOOTH = 0.0, then no smoothing is done.
 
 Normally some smoothing is required to avoid jagged velocity contours when
 converting from offset to angle.  Typical values of LEN_SMOOTH are from
 0.1 s to 0.5 s.
 
 Active only when OPT_SR = NO.

Help.Tip: Use the inaccurate Straight Ray method to convert offset to angle.
Help.Text:
psninv - OPT_SR
Use the inaccurate Straight Ray method to convert offset to angle.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES/NO
 The OPT_SR = YES option is included for historical reasons, or to compare
 with contractor processed data, as some contractors may still be using such
 a method for calculating gradients.  If OPT_SR = NO, an improved conversion
 from offset to angle is used.

Help.Tip: Choose PATH_WVLT using a file selection dialog box.
Help.Text:
psninv - SELECT_PATH_WVLT
Choose PATH_WVLT using a file selection dialog box.

Help.Tip: Pathname of wavelet file for starting and reference model
Help.Text:
psninv - PATH_WVLT
Pathname of wavelet file for starting and reference model
 
 Default = NONE
 Allowed = char
 If you specify PATH_WVLT, the wavelet in this file is used in the inversion
 as the starting and the reference model.
 
 This file may be in TRCIO or SEGY format or any other format readable by the
 TRCIO primitives in CPS. Only the first trace in your file will be read.
 
 If PATH_WVLT = NONE, then program will generate a random wavelet
 as the starting wavelet, with the L2 norm of the data. The reference
 wavelet will have zero norm.

Help.Tip: Status of PATH_WVLT.
Help.Text:
psninv - PATH_WVLT_INFO
Status of PATH_WVLT.

Help.Tip: Actual time for first sample of the wavelet, in seconds.
Help.Text:
psninv - TIM_FIRST
Actual time for first sample of the wavelet, in seconds.
 
 Default = 0.0 (or read from wavelet file)
 Allowed = real
 Time of first sample in wavelet is used for proper centering of the
 wavelet (same as in wavelets used by DSIG, although correctness of the
 centering time is more critical here than it is in DSIG).
 
 As in the case of DSIG, the front end will attempt to read the TMIN value
 from your wavelet file (if that file exists already when building the job
 containing psninv) and will use this as the default for TIM_FIRST; however,
 you may override this setting manually, if necessary.
 
 If your wavelet is in a SEGY file, the TMIN extracted from the file will
 always be 0.0 (because SEGY format doesn't support non-zero TMIN), so you'll
 have to know the correct TIM_FIRST value independently.  If you extracted
 your wavelet using interactive inversion software you probably determined
 its TIM_FIRST value quite accurately in the extraction process.  If your
 estimated wavelet was calculated by C4WE, the TMIN in your wavelet file is
 only very approximate; in this case, we recommend analyzing it with SPCT to
 determine a more accurate TIM_FIRST before using this wavelet in psninv.
 
 TIM_FIRST is always active.

Help.Tip: Length of operator for start, ref and output wavelet, in seconds.
Help.Text:
psninv - LEN_OP
Length of operator for start, ref and output wavelet, in seconds.
 
 Default = -
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 LEN_OP should be approximately the same as the wavelet length.
 
 LEN_OP is always active.

Help.Tip: Button that removes this process parameter screen.
Help.Text:
psninv - CLOSE
Button that removes this process parameter screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Appears only on the view-only process parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
Help.Text:
psninv - OK
Button to accept parameter values, run traps and remove screen.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values, runs the parameter traps and removes
 the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
Help.Text:
psninv - APPLY
Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that accepts parameter values and runs the parameter traps but does
 not remove the parameter screen.

Help.Tip: Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
Help.Text:
psninv - CANCEL
Button to remove the parameter screen without changing parameters.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =

Help.Tip: Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
Help.Text:
psninv - RESET
Set parameters to their initial value or last applied value.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that sets the parameters back to their values when the screen appeared
 or to their last applied value.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
Help.Text:
psninv - PROCESSLISTLEFT
Accept the current parameters and move to the previous process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the previous process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
Help.Text:
psninv - PROCESSLIST
Menu of processes in the current workfile and their number.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Menu that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to any chosen process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
Help.Text:
psninv - PROCESSLISTRIGHT
Accept the current parameters and move to the next process.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that allows the user to accept the current parameter values, run the
 parameter traps and move to the next process in the current workfile.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
Help.Text:
psninv - PROJECTDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as Project Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as Project Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of Project Defaults for a project.

Help.Tip: Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
Help.Text:
psninv - USERDEFAULT
Save the current parameter values as User Defaults.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 Button that saves the current parameter values as User Defaults for this
 process.  There will be one set of User Defaults for a userid.

Help.Tip: Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
Help.Text:
psninv - HELP
Allows the user to access the pop-up Help Window.
 
 Default =
 Allowed =
 The Help Window allows access to three kinds of help:  Parameter Help, CPS
 Process Help and Application (CFE) Help.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : PSNINV   (PreStack Nonlinear INVersion for AVA parameters
                        and source wavelet)
 Category   : diagnostics
 Written    : 2003-07-28   by: Partha Routh
 Revised    : 2006-10-31   by: Partha Routh
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Generate various AVA gradient related products & source wavelet.
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : No.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 PSNINV produces various AVA gradient related output products, including
 Source wavelet. PSNINV can be used to produce AVA gradient as a final product,
 but typically it is used to provide input data to FFAVA and PSLINV processes.
 
 
      OPT_INPUT = OFFSET, The input to the code is moveout CIP gathers
      So the data are NON-NMO-corrected CIP gathers with trace offset in
      header word 6.
 
 
 Intercept-Gradient Calculation
 
 
 If OPT_INPUT = OFFSET, psninv fits each input CMP gather with src wavelet and
 reflectivity model given by:
 
               r(x,t0) = A(t0) + B(t0)*(sin(angle)**2),
 
 where x is offset, t0 is the zero-offset travel time, A is the intercept and
 B is the gradient.  The sine of the reflection angle is approximated by:
 
                   sin(angle) = (x*VI)/(t*(VR**2)),
 
 where VR = stacking (RMS) velocity, VI = interval velocity (related to VR
 by the Dix equation) and t = reflection time derived from the NMO equation:
 
                  t = sqrt( t0**2 + (x**2)/(VR**2) ).
 
 Normally, an interval velocity derived from the RMS velocity by the Dix
 equation is a jagged function of time and should be smoothed for use in
 converting offset to angle.  LEN_SMOOTH is the length of a running average
 smoothing operator, in seconds, that is applied to the interval velocity.
 Typical values of LEN_SMOOTH are from 0.1 s to 0.5 s.
 
 
 Straight Ray Offset-Angle Conversion
 
 Prior to September 1995, ASTK (the precursor to psninv) used an inaccurate
 offset-angle conversion based on a straight ray approximation, equivalent to
 the approximation described earlier with the further simplification that
 VI = VR; thus, the assumed relation between offset and angle was:
 
                         sin(angle) = x/(t*VR),
 
 which uses only the RMS velocity and makes no use of interval velocity.
 For reflections at depth, this equation may underestimate reflection angle
 by around a factor of two.  Setting OPT_SR = YES causes psninv to use this
 inaccurate method.  This option is provided for historical interest or for
 comparison with contractor-processed data since some contractors may still
 compute AVA gradients this way.  Normally, OPT_SR should be set to NO.
 
 
 Gradient Related Products Available
 
 If OPT_INPUT = OFFSET, psninv first fits the input CMP as described
 above and extracts an intercept trace, gradient trace and a source trace.
 PSNINV then calculates the desired gradient related product based on
 these intercept and gradient traces
 (or may optionally produce MODEL or RESID output to indicate the quality of
 data fitting).
 
     If OPT_OUTPUT = A_B_SRC, the intercept, gradient and src traces are output
     in three-trace gathers (thus, 3 output traces per input gather). Here, the
     intercept trace will be the first trace, gradient the second trace
     in each three-trace output gather.
 
     If OPT_OUTPUT = DA_DB_SRC, the perturbed intercept, grad and src traces
     are output in three-trace gathers (thus, 3 O/P traces per input gather).
     The perturbed intercept trace will be the first trace, perturbed gradient
     the second trace in each three-trace output gather.
 
     If OPT_OUTPUT = P_REFL, a P-wave reflectivity trace at angle ANG_REF
     is output with source trace.(2 trace per gather.)
     A(t0) + B(t0)*(sin(ANGREF)**2).
     When ANGREF = 0, this shows perturbations in log(P-Impedance). For
     non-zero ANGREF, it represents perturbations in the logarithm of an
     "Elastic Impedance" (Patrick Connolly, Leading Edge, April 1999).
 
     If OPT_OUTPUT = S_REFL, an estimated S-wave reflectivity trace at normal
     incidence is output along with source trace.
     (2 trace per input gather.)  0.5*( A(t0) - B(t0)).
 
     If OPT_OUTPUT = VS_VP, an estimated VS/VP ratio trace plus source trace
      is output.
     (Two trace per input gather.)  -0.5*( A(t0) + B(t0)).  Note that this has
     the opposite polarity of a Poisson's ratio stack.
 
     If OPT_OUTPUT = AB_PROD, the product of the intercept times the gradient
     traces plus source trace is output.  (2 trace per input gather.)
     This highlights bright spots with both large amplitudes and large AVA
     changes (Rutherford & Williams Class 3).
 
     If OPT_OUTPUT = MODEL, psninv outputs predicted data (as many traces
     per gather as in the input traces). along with three other traces,
     intercept,  gradient and source trace.
 
     If OPT_PROD = RESID, the observed data minus the predicted data is output
     along with three other traces, intercept, gradient and source trace.
 
 
 Velocity Handling
 
 Manipulation of the velocities needed for converting offset to angle when
 OPT_INPUT = OFFSET depends on settings of OPT_AVE and OPT_SR and is designed
 to follow the treatment in process AVAST as closely as possible. As in AVAST,
 you may input Stacking or RMS velocities (type VTNM or VTRM) or Interval
 velocities (type VTIN).
 
 If OPT_AVE = YES, velocity functions are combined to arrive at a single
 interval velocity function: If input velocities are of type VTNM or VTRM,
 they are first resampled to the trace sample interval, then averaged, then
 converted to interval velocity using Dix's formula. If they are of type
 VTIN, they are resampled to the trace sample interval (honoring the constant
 interval velocity "steps"), then averaged. In either case, the composited
 interval velocity is then smoothed using the LEN_SMOOTH parameter. This
 smoothed interval velocity is also converted to RMS velocity, because both
 interval and RMS velocities are needed in our approximate offset-to-angle
 conversion formula.
 
 If OPT_AVE = NO, a smoothed interval velocity and corresponding RMS velocity
 is derived separately at every velocity location and saved in a table. When
 processing traces, interval and RMS velocities are interpolated separately
 from the stored table to the current CMP location.
 
 The intent of the OPT_AVE = NO option is to be able to accommodate a SLOWLY
 varying water depth.  It is up to you to put in functions which have a smooth
 lateral variation. It is NOT recommended that the option be used with raw
 stacking velocites.
 
 If OPT_SR = YES, velocity handling is as described above, except that no
 smoothing is done, and only the RMS velocity is used (You may still input
 interval velocities, if you wish, even when OPT_SR = YES).
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
 Input Data Preparation
 
 If OPT_INPUT = OFFSET, input data should be non-NMO-corrected CMP gathers,
 preferably with multiples attenuated.
 Data should be muted (head and tail) to remove
 noise or any data that might be misinterpreted by PSNINV.  Use a zero length
 taper in MUTE to avoid tapers that PSNINV might interpret as AVA gradients.
 
 If OPT_INPUT = OFFSET, header word 6 for each input trace should be set to
 the center value of the offset range that trace represents.
 
 Output Traces
 
 If output traces from psninv will be inverted using PSLINV, do not apply any
 amplitude balance between psninv and PSLINV. On the other hand, if output
 traces will be sent to FFAVA, an MVXP is usually applied between psninv and
 FFAVA.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         PSNINV REVISION HISTORY
 
     Date        Author      Description
     ----        ------      -----------
  2. 2006-10-31  Routh       Beta version checks.
  1. 2003-07-01  Routh       First version of PSNINV was developed
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
